I had a great conversation with Chaz Wolfe on the Driven to Win Podcast recently and I'm excited to share a sneak peek here!

We spoke about all things IPO, how to build your business to go public and my personal favorite the mindset you need to win.

I loved that we could speak candidly about how entrepreneurs can pull themselves up when they’re at a low point, what I do when I’m at a low point, and how it can be so important to focus on your ‘why’.

So much of being an entrepreneur is about the business, the drive, the time management, and the market, but it’s also about being human, having the humility to share your failures, and being honest about your journey.

You don’t have to hit rock bottom to make a change in your journey; you can start right now. Today.

The Olympic Effect

The Olympic Games are not only about celebrating the World’s top athletes, as highlighted by Team USA’s recent (and arguably better than the Dream Team) men’s basketball gold medal victory. 

The Games also play a significant role in influencing financial markets, particularly in the host country.

Historically, as you can imagine, the infrastructure investments, increased tourism, and global visibility associated with the Olympics have driven short-term market optimism and economic activity.

The 2008 Beijing Olympics saw massive infrastructure development that boosted China’s economic growth. However, the 2016 Rio Olympics highlighted potential risks, as Brazil’s struggling economy faced increased debt without substantial long-term gains.

LA has been selected as the 2028 host of the Summer Olympic Games, and it’s worth noting that the last time LA hosted the Olympics in 1984, it turned a reported $223 million profit ($670 million in today’s dollars).

Investors often view the anticipation of the Olympics as an opportunity, driving market performance in the lead-up to the Games.

While the short-term economic benefits of the Olympics can be significant—much like Team USA's ability to rally and secure gold—the long-term impact hinges on how effectively the host country leverages the momentum. 

Some analysts argue that designing permanent host cities for the Olympics could mitigate the immense budgets and last-minute preparations frequently challenging host nations.

What are your thoughts? Who were you rooting for this year?

The Quiet $4 Billion IPO

Earlier this month, Lineage, the world’s largest real estate investment trust for temperature-controlled warehouses went public on Nasdaq for a whopping $4.4 billion. 

The biggest IPO of the year so far. 

Surprisingly, the event drew little attention, even though it’s been the biggest IPO of 2024 since Arm brought in $4.87 billion when it went public on Nasdaq last September. 

It’s an indication that the markets are looking up. 

Klarna is also gearing up to IPO, likely at the beginning of next year where they are looking at a potential $20 billion valuation.

The pipeline is strong and there is hopeful optimism about 2025.

Don’t Toss Out the Good with the Bad

Nasdaq is considering removing some of the appeals process for penny stocks that are at risk of being delisted, making it harder for these stocks to avoid or delay removal from the Exchange.

Currently, stocks trading below $1 are given 180 days to regain compliance, with the possibility of an additional 180-day extension before facing delisting.

The proposed changes would tighten the rules for companies using reverse stock splits to avoid delisting. If a company’s stock price falls below $1 within a year after a reverse split, it could face immediate delisting.

Nasdaq views this behavior as a sign of deep financial or operational distress, making such companies unsuitable for continued trading on its exchange.

Nasdaq’s proposed rule changes are part of a broader effort to enhance market quality and protect investors. By raising the bar, Nasdaq ensures that its listed companies reflect the strength and resilience investors expect.

However, it’s important to note that many undervalued companies with stocks trading below $1 may be underperforming for reasons unrelated to financial distress. Companies relying on extended appeals or reverse stock splits to maintain their listing will need to reassess their strategies.

But there's good news!

Emmis Capital and Exchange Listing can assist these companies with financing, restructuring, and guiding them back to good standing with Nasdaq. 

If you are a stakeholder in one of these companies, feel free to contact me to discuss a potential collaboration.

This company outpaced Apple, Microsoft, and Google for 25 years

Rodney Sacks and Hilton Schlosberg, two South African entrepreneurs, have turned Monster Beverage Corporation into a powerhouse in the global energy drink market. 

Their journey began in 1990 when they acquired the struggling Hansen Natural Corporation, which had its roots in a juice business dating back to the 1930s.

In 2002, in a pivotal moment, the company launched Monster Energy, which propelled the business to new heights. This success led to a rebranding of the company in 2012 as Monster Beverage Corporation. 

Today, Monster is sold in 141 countries and owns a significant share of the $53 billion global energy drink market.

Over the last 25 years, Monster Beverage’s stock has delivered extraordinary returns, making it the best-performing stock in the United States between April 1999 and April 2024. 

Sacks and Schlosberg's strategic vision and leadership turned the company into a global success and made them billionaires, ranking them among the world’s wealthiest individuals.

As Sacks prepares to transition from his role as co-CEO in 2025, the legacy of their partnership and the empire they've built continues to solidify their place as two of the most successful value creators in modern business history.

The "Other" Elephant in the room

In our daily lives, we often encounter the proverbial "elephant in the room" - glaring issues everyone sees but no one addresses. 

Yet, there's another kind of elephant, the one beneath the surface, the deeper truths about people and situations that we might miss if we only focus on the obvious.

I recently had the privilege of visiting an elephant sanctuary in Thailand, home to elephants rescued from abuse and neglect, providing them with a safe haven to recover and thrive. 

Standing beside these amazing creatures, feeding them, and bathing in the mud WITH them was a transformative experience. 

Elephants are known for their incredible memory—knowing they remember the abuse. Yet, they welcome humans into their space and allow themselves to be cared for by humans taught me a valuable lesson in resilience.

Just like these elephants, people carry their own hidden stories. We often see only the surface: their actions, words, and appearances. But beneath that surface lies a wealth of experiences, emotions, and memories that shape who they are. 

In essence, the "other" elephant isn't just about what's unspoken or ignored in a room. It's about the unseen layers within each person.

My visit to the sanctuary was a stark reminder to truly connect with others and by seeing past the surface, we can build more meaningful connections.

Don't Let the Bull Die

In the world of business and finance, it's easy to be swept away by the allure of market perceptions and the temptation to overvalue your entrepreneurial venture. I recently came across a fable that perfectly illustrates this pitfall.

The story involves two men in a village who own a cow. They decide to sell the cow back and forth to each other, agreeing to raise its price with each transaction. Each time they exchange ownership, they mark a paper profit.

The villagers, witnessing the rising price, begin to believe in the cow's exceptional value.

As news spreads, more villagers express interest in buying the cow, and the two men continue to inflate its price, enjoying the illusion of wealth. On the surface, they appear to be savvy businessmen profiting from a rapidly appreciating asset.

However, the illusion shatters when the cow unexpectedly dies. The two men are left with nothing of real value, and the villagers realize the cow was never worth the inflated price.

This story is a stark reminder of what can happen with company valuations. Companies can be valued based on inflated perceptions driven by hype and speculation rather than solid fundamentals.

As excitement builds, investors may rush to buy in, believing in the company’s perceived value. However, if the company's performance and intrinsic worth don't support this perception, the illusion can quickly crumble, leaving all stakeholders with significant losses.

As entrepreneurs and stakeholders, we are better served by creating and identifying lasting value and recognizing the risks when valuations are driven up beyond their true worth, leading to eventual collapse.

After all, the real measure of success lies in building sustainable, value-driven businesses.

I discuss company valuations when going to market for an IPO in my book which I'm currently giving away for free! You can get your copy here: https://lnkd.in/dyfjTPcZ

You do not have to be an expert at everything!

If there’s one lesson I’ve learned over and over in my entrepreneurial journey, it’s that by trying to be an expert at everything, you’re diluting your strengths.

I consider myself to be a dynamic entrepreneur with multiple areas of expertise and interest, but I am not an expert at everything...

... and here’s why that’s a good thing!

-      Focus on Core Strengths: I can work on delivering exceptional value in certain areas by recognizing and honing in on my core strengths. 

-      Building Strong Teams: Acknowledging that I’m not an expert in every field allows me to surround myself with talented individuals who complement my skills. This diversity within a team leads to more robust decision-making and creativity.

-      Continuous Learning: Accepting that I don’t know it all fuels my drive to learn and grow. It encourages a mindset of curiosity and adaptability, which is essential for an entrepreneur and leader.

-      Enhanced Collaboration: Acknowledging my knowledge gaps fosters a culture of collaboration. It promotes open communication and encourages team members to share their insights and expertise, leading to a more inclusive and innovative work environment.

Leveraging the collective expertise of those around us can achieve remarkable success.

I invite my LinkedIn network to reach out, send me a message, and let's explore opportunities for collaboration. 

Let's work together to create something extraordinary!

No more analysis paralysis

Entrepreneurship is a journey full of decision-making. Every choice, from strategic directions to daily operations, shapes the future of your business. 

But, it’s not simply a process of choosing one thing over another, entrepreneurial decisions can be complex and risky.

I’ve had to learn a process and to trust myself when making decisions, something many entrepreneurs struggle with.

The good news is that decision-making is a skill that can be strengthened; here’s how:

-      Use data: By using the empirical data and analytical tools available you can create a foundation to base your decision on. 

However, many entrepreneurs need to think independently and don't have the time or energy to gather data before deciding.

-      Use intuition: Intuition steps in when data is incomplete or ambiguous. Gut feelings often reflect the insights gained through extensive experience.

The balance of both data and intuition is where the magic lies and by reflecting on past decisions, good or bad; you can interpret where your strengths (and weaknesses are).

A $25 Billion IPO Blunder

Bill Ackman, well known for his impressive track record as an investor, is not an equity syndicate banker and he learned this the hard way for the Pershing Square USA IPO. 

Initially aiming for a record-breaking $25 billion, the offering was significantly downsized to $2.5-$4 billion and last week was withdrawn.

Traditionally, in an IPO underwriters manage intricate communications with investors, to balance  strict compliance requirements with marketing and investor communicaitons. 

However, when CEOs intervene directly, problems can occur. 

In a letter to investors, Ackman prematurely disclosed key investor names and urged immediate orders, bypassing established protocols. Doing this led to regulatory complications and delayed approvals from the SEC.

The Pershing Square IPO highlights the critical importance of adherence to compliance standards and the value of relying on professionals for managing complex IPO processes.

As the company prepares to revisit the market, it is a reminder that even experienced leaders must respect the established norms and expertise within equity syndicate banking. 

Clear, compliant communications and realistic market expectations will be crucial for future success.

Vision, Execution, and Manifestation:

I recently completed a journey across three continents, embodying my philosophy of integration. 

This journey showcased the power of intentionality and strategic planning in creating impactful experiences to drive business achievements and extraordinary personal experiences.

These are some of my reflections from my recent travels:

Vision: Every great endeavor begins with a clear vision. My goal was to immerse myself in learning, leadership, business cultures, new markets, and strategic partnerships while expanding my personal and professional horizons.

Execution: With any solid plan, execution is paramount. My travels included an educational program in Europe, a leadership program and family time in the States, and business development in four Southeast Asian countries. 

These were integrated with cultural experiences, family, friends, personal reflection, and adventures that created lifelong memories.

Manifestation: Traveling across three continents wasn't just a trip; it was a manifestation of what it means for me to live and lead as an Integrated CEO. 

As the trip unfolded, new relationships and business opportunities emerged, innovative ideas were sparked, and intrinsic value was created.

This experience demonstrated how vision, precise execution, and the power of manifestation can lead to extraordinary outcomes. 

These principles are the cornerstone of achieving unparalleled success in both business and personal endeavors.

Now it is time to put all that was learned and experienced into action.

Stay inspired, stay integrated.

What I’ve Learned about Self-Leadership

Having been a CEO and entrepreneur for over 35 years, I’ve deepened my understanding of the impact of self-leadership on achieving sustainable success and high performance.

Self-leadership, in my own definition, is the practice of intentionally influencing your own thoughts, behaviors, and emotions to achieve your personal and professional goals. It involves self-awareness, self-discipline, and the ability to motivate oneself. 

By setting clear objectives, managing time effectively, and maintaining a positive mindset, self-leadership enables individuals to navigate challenges and drive their success with integrity and resilience.

Embracing these principles has had a transformative impact on my ability to lead with purpose and vision, adapt to changes, and stay ahead of the curve.

I invite you to commit to self-leadership to achieve remarkable personal and business outcomes. The impact is profound and far-reaching, enabling not just success but fulfillment.

The Microcap Company Combatting Fake News

Israeli AI startup Cyabra, specializing in tracking fake profiles and disinformation on social media, is planning to IPO on Nasdaq via a merger with Trailblazer Merger Corporation, valuing the company at $70 million.
 
Cyabra’s machine-learning platform identifies malicious actors and AI-generated fake content. 

Founded in 2018 by veterans of elite Israeli intelligence units, Cyabra has collaborated with 19 governments and major brands like Warner Media to counter disinformation. 

Did you know that the World Economic Forum lists AI-driven misinformation as a top global risk?

With significant challenges posed by AI-generated fake news, Cyabra has been instrumental in identifying and mitigating these kinds of threats. 

Elon Musk hired Cyabra to analyze fake accounts during his acquisition of Twitter (now X) and made a startling discovery; 13% of the platform’s accounts were inauthentic. 

The startup, which has raised $16 million from investors like Founders Fund and OurCrowd, plans to expand its team by 20 to 30 people within the next 6 to 12 months.

As demand for AI explodes, I see companies like Cyabra becoming valuable safeguards for protecting democracy and truth.

The Company that said ‘No Thanks’ to Google.

Last week, Cybersecurity startup Wiz Inc, turned down a $23 billion takeover offer from Alphabet, opting instead for an IPO- in the future.

Wiz decided it could ultimately be worth more as a public company and there are many more positives to saying no.

“Saying no to such humbling offers is tough, but with our exceptional team, I feel confident in making that choice,” Wiz Chief Executive Officer Assaf Rappaport said in a memo to employees.

Staying independent has allowed Wiz to maintain control, capitalize on its market, and continue its rapid growth trajectory and innovation in cybersecurity, ultimately aiming to create greater long-term value for its stakeholders.

This is a great example of why I recommend that companies explore an IPO as an exit strategy and as an alternative to M&A, Venture, or PE capital.

This is also one of the reasons I started Emmis Capital LLC; to support companies pursuing an IPO and access to transformational capital and liquidity into capital markets.

Fraudulent Tweets?

Last week, federal prosecutors charged Andrew Left, an activist short seller and analyst, with securities fraud for allegedly using his public platform to manipulate stock market activity.

Left may have profited at least $16 million from 2018 to 2023. 

Left and his hedge fund, Citron Capital, now face additional civil fraud charges by the SEC, accused of a $20 million scheme involving false trading recommendations for 23 companies. 

That civil complaint in Los Angeles federal court accused Left and Citron of “engaging in a $20 million multi-year scheme to defraud followers by publishing false and misleading statements regarding his supposed stock trading recommendations.”

The action alleges fraudulent conduct relating to 23 companies on at least 26 occasions.

The indictment alleges Left coordinated with hedge funds to disseminate short reports, manipulate stock prices, and profit from advanced knowledge of market movements. 

Left denies wrongdoing, claiming compliance with all laws.

Early in my entrepreneurial journey, my focus was on strategy, innovation, and growth.

Lace up your boots!

As an entrepreneur, deciding whether to bootstrap or seek outside investment is huge.

Here’s my 2 cents:

When to Bootstrap:
----> Control: If full control over your business is a priority, bootstrapping allows you to make decisions independently.
----> Market Validation: For early stages, bootstrapping is best to tighten operations, and validate your market and business model without external pressure.
----> Minimal Capital Needs: If your business has low capital requirements, bootstrapping proves higher ROI. 
----> Long-Term Vision: Bootstrapping is ideal if you have a long-term vision and are willing to grow slowly.

When to Seek Investment:
----> Rapid Growth: External funding can provide the necessary resources if your business model requires rapid scaling to seize market opportunities.
----> High Capital Needs: For businesses requiring significant upfront capital expenditures, seeking investment is often necessary.
----> Market Competition: If competitors are well-funded, securing investment can help level the playing field.
----> Network and Expertise: Investors can provide valuable networks and expertise beyond just capital.

Consider this:
----> Business Stage: Early-stage businesses may benefit more from bootstrapping, while those in growth stages might need investment.
----> Risk Tolerance: Evaluate your risk tolerance and financial stability. Outside investment brings pressure but also potential rewards.
----> Strategic Fit: Ensure any investment aligns with your business goals and vision.

Assess your business and capital needs, market conditions, and your preferences to make the best decision.

If you’ve ever heard me talk about ‘microcap’ IPOs and thought, ‘What the heck does microcap mean?’

This one is for you!

A micro-cap company has a market capitalization of $50 million to $300 million. 

So, what is market capitalization?

It’s the number of shares issued and outstanding multiplied by the current price of the stock. 

If your market cap is $50 million or more, you’re eligible to go public on NASDAQ, NYSE, and the CBOE.

But Peter, isn’t that too small to go public? 

Nope! You don’t have to be a unicorn to go public.

So why would you want to go public?

To get access to capital and grow your company as an alternative to venture capital.

What’s your trust score?

If you had to score everyone around you on how much you trust them, how many would get 10/10?

If you want to be a better leader (or CEO, entrepreneur, friend, or partner), you need to build people’s trust.

Building trust is essential for entrepreneurs. 

Every interaction with clients, employees, colleagues, and even how you conduct yourself with family and friends builds or breaks trust.

Want to up your trust score?

---->Embrace Transparency: Foster a culture of openness about your business operations and decisions. Clear communication builds credibility.

----> Champion Consistency: Deliver on your promises consistently. Reliability is a cornerstone of trust.

----> Really Listen: Pay close attention and deeply engage with your clients' and associates' needs and feedback. Show that you value their input. 

----> Commit to Ethical Excellence: Adhere to the highest ethical standards in all business dealings. Integrity is key to long-term relationships.

----> Be Unwaveringly Professional: (Especially when you don’t think anyone is watching) Maintain a high standard of professionalism in all interactions.

Building trust takes time but is crucial for sustainable success in business. 

What strategies have you found effective in building trust? Share your thoughts below!

You’ve taken your company public… now what?

It's a huge achievement for founders and entrepreneurs.

An IPO provides access to capital and increased visibility and credibility.

As Dan Rosenweig, CEO of Chegg once said: “The good parts about being a public company are increased discipline, increased execution, and increased transparency to make sure that you are really building a company for a hundred years.”

But now you’re playing the long game.  

The challenges faced by entrepreneurs do not magically vanish after an IPO. Rather, a new set of challenges arise.

These are just a few of the challenges you can expect as a public company:

·      Increased Regulatory Requirements: Companies must adhere to stringent SEC reporting and disclosure rules.

·      Transparency and Disclosure: Higher levels of transparency are necessary.

·      Public and Investor Scrutiny: Companies face more scrutiny from investors and media.

·      Shareholder Pressure: Management answers to a broader group of shareholders.

·      Market Fluctuations: Stock prices fluctuate based on market conditions and performance.

This is why it's vital to create strategies that help to balance growth, transparency, regulatory compliance, and shareholder value.

I talk about the realities of being public in the final chapter of my book. I’m also grateful to my good friend, Vlado Bosanac, who provided invaluable knowledge in this chapter.

The pressure is on... but it doesn't have to be.

Being an entrepreneur and CEO means constantly dealing with immense pressure to succeed while managing expectations for both yourself and others. 

Over the years, I've learned skills to help me handle this pressure effectively. 

Here’s how I manage expectations for myself and my team:

----> SMART Goals: Break down big objectives into Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound milestones to stay focused and progress clearly.

----> Prioritize Wellness: Regular exercise, meditation, and quality sleep are non-negotiables. A healthy mind and body are the foundation for effective leadership.

----> Radical Humility and Transparency: Open, honest communication builds trust.

----> Providing regular updates and setting clear expectations keep everyone aligned and accountable.

----> Invest in Lifelong Learning: Continuous learning and seeking mentorship are key. Staying adaptable and informed helps navigate challenges with confidence.

----> Learn from Setbacks: Viewing failures as learning opportunities reduces pressure and fosters a growth mindset. Every setback is a step toward success.

As my toughest critic, I’ve learned to manage my expectations, celebrate all wins—especially the small ones—and understand that perfection is a journey, not a destination. 

By implementing these strategies, I've learned to create a balanced, productive environment where we can all can thrive.

Are You the Master of Your Time?

When you're a CEO juggling multiple hats, tasks, and priorities, effective time management is not just a skill—it’s a necessity. 

I’ve refined my approach throughout my career to maximize productivity and achieve sustained success.

----> Prioritization with Precision
Prioritizing tasks is about strategic alignment. Early on, I realized that aligning daily tasks with long-term goals is crucial. 

I use the Eisenhower Matrix to ensure every action supports strategic objectives. 

This matrix categorizes tasks into four quadrants:
----> Urgent and Important: Tasks that need immediate attention and contribute to long-term goals.

----> Important but Not Urgent: Tasks that are crucial for long-term success but don’t require immediate action.

----> Urgent but Not Important: Tasks that must be done quickly but don’t significantly impact long-term goals.

----> Neither Urgent nor Important: Tasks that have little to no value and can be minimized or eliminated.

This simple yet effective approach helps me focus on what drives the business forward.

Are there any tools you use to manage your time better?

The Big Day has arrived!  
 
 
The listing day is a momentous day and in some ways like a birthday and grand unveiling day for many companies. 
 
It’s the day the company is initiated into the public markets and begins trading as a public entity. 
 
It’s a huge moment for any company and the culmination of years of hard work. 
 
Newly listed IPO companies face challenges like market volatility, investor skepticism, reporting, and intense competition for capital in the current market. 
 
It’s a huge responsibility, which is why I always recommend that companies begin planning early and ‘acting’ as public entities, well before going public. 
 
I discuss all the realities of the ‘big day’ in chapter 11 of my book and welcome the expert knowledge of Paul Dorfman, the head of listings at the NYSE. 
 
There’s nothing quite like the experience of IPO day and hope all entrepreneurs get to experience it in their lifetime!

I sensed that an issuer-based offering would attract CEOs preparing for when the IPO market responses and future market opportunities. 

I conducted a thorough market analysis and consulted industry experts to validate this.

This fusion of intuition and data provided the confidence to proceed with a strategy fine-tuned to current conditions. 

Mastering both data-driven and intuitive decision-making is crucial for effective leadership and long-term success.

“Man: a being in search of meaning.” – Plato

How do entrepreneurs find meaning in their lives?

There is no right or wrong answer here.

For some, their sense of purpose and meaning is derived from creating, for some it’s starting companies that help others and for others, it’s an innate drive that comes from following their passions, values, and long-term goals.

I’ve found that there are three critical elements:

-----> Pursuing Passion and Purpose: Many entrepreneurs start businesses based on their passion. Turning a passion into a career can provide deep fulfillment and a sense of purpose.

-----> Creating Impact: Entrepreneurs often seek to positively impact their communities or the world. Whether through innovation, providing jobs, or improving lives, the ability to effect change can be profoundly meaningful.

-----> Personal Fulfillment: The entrepreneurial journey offers personal and professional growth, where learning, overcoming challenges, achieving milestones, and balancing work with personal life lead to a deep sense of accomplishment and satisfaction.

By focusing on these aspects, entrepreneurs can cultivate a meaningful and fulfilling life that goes beyond financial success

What do WWII tunnels in London, have to do with Amsterdam?

The London Tunnels is a company planning to develop the Kingsway Exchange Tunnels built in the 1940s. 

The tunnels were intended to shelter up to 8000 people during the war. 

Their goal is to launch the tunnels as historical and cultural attractions in 2027.

Last week the company announced its plans to IPO on Amsterdam’s Euronext, hoping to raise £20m to £30m. 

Considering the tunnels are owned by a British company, and built by the British government, for the defence of Britain, it’s unexpected that the company would choose the Euronext to list. 

That said, according to the company chair Peter Curtin, listing on the leading pan-European market would allow investors to acquire shares in “what is likely to be the last major historical and heritage attraction that can be reopened in central London.”

There’s an interesting history behind the tunnels and while they are still owned by British Telecom, London Tunnels plans to buy the site from BT next year and has plans to reinstate the city's deepest London bar, which closed in the 1080s.

It’s Show Time! 
 
 
I’m sure you’ve heard the term IPO Roadshow before. Have you wondered why it happens? 
 
An IPO roadshow is a series of presentations made by a company's management team to potential investors before going public.  
 
The purpose is to generate interest and demand for the company's shares, providing detailed information about its business model, financial performance, market potential, and growth strategies.  
 
It typically involves traveling to major financial hubs and meeting with institutional investors, analysts, and fund managers.  
 
The feedback and interest garnered during the roadshow help the company set the final IPO price and assess investor appetite for its shares, so it’s a pretty important time for the company. 
 
The company will also be getting a lot of feedback during this time and the feedback can be both positive and negative. 
 
There are some steps you can take to ensure your feedback is as good as it can be, and I go over these in my book, if you’re interested (check out the comments for where to find it). 
 
Thank you to Andrew Tucker for sharing his knowledge in this chapter.

I know how easy it is to pour everything into building a business.

I’ve done it repeatedly, having started my first business at 24 and my first exit at 30. 

Since then, I’ve taken my own companies public and been a founder, investor and advisor to so many others. 

Most people will tell you that you should strive for balance.

But I’m not sure balance exists for entrepreneurs. 

When you’re so passionate and excited about something, putting in the work is easy at first. 

The problem comes when you’re constantly tipping the scales and you’re missing out on important time spent with family and friends.

But here's what I do know.

Integrating work and life is key.

Achieving integration can accelerate your success and make the journey more enjoyable.

Ensure that while you're pursuing your goals, you also strive to maintain integration in your life.

There are no perks of being a wallflower.

When it comes to succeeding at business, you have to put yourself out there.

If I did not have a network of lawyers, advisors, auditors, bankers, and countless others, I would not be able to do what I do today.

Networking and investing time into professional relationships is not only valuable it’s necessary.

Here’s why:
·      Access to Opportunities: Networking opens doors to new business opportunities, partnerships, and collaborations that you might not have discovered otherwise.

·      Knowledge Sharing: It allows you to share and gain insights, advice, and feedback from other experienced entrepreneurs and industry experts.

·      Support System: Building a network provides emotional and professional support, helping you navigate the challenges of entrepreneurship.

·      Visibility and Influence: Regular networking can increase your visibility and establish you as a knowledgeable and influential figure in your industry.

·      Resource Pooling: A strong network can help you find the right talent, investors, and mentors, accelerating your business growth.

·      Market Insights: Networking helps you stay updated on market trends, customer needs, and industry changes, enabling you to make informed decisions.

I’ve come to learn that networking is not just about ‘meeting people'.

It’s about building meaningful relationships that can support and propel your entrepreneurial journey forward as you do the same for others.

Fail to prepare… prepare to fail

More and more companies are starting to see the value in preparing to IPO well before they might be ready.

What many don’t realize about going public is that it’s a marathon, not a sprint.

Like any sporting endeavor, there are two phases, preparation and execution.
Pre-IPO processes are typically carried out for up to twelve to eighteen months, sometimes more. 

Andy MacKinnon, CFO of Moonpig, led the company’s £1.2bn IPO in 2021 during an accelerated five-month timeframe – without extensive prior preparation. 

He later said, “Looking back this was a remarkable achievement, but it also created a lot of stress. I would recommend starting the preparation work ahead of time to avoid this pressure.”

Many successful IPOs today credit the fact that they have been preparing for this event for months if not years.

I frequently talk about the value of preparing to go public and talk extensively about it in Chapter 9 of my book as well.

If you have no idea if your company is ready to IPO, Exchange Listing offers an IPO Readiness Overview, which can help your company get prepared.

You don’t have to hit rock bottom to change.

During an extreme period of hardship from the great recession, it took me hitting rock bottom to get serious about my health.

I no longer take my health for granted.

Instead, it’s at the forefront of my mind on a daily basis.

Entrepreneurs often neglect their well-being in the pursuit of success. 

Today, I am healthier at 61 than I was a decade ago.    
                                                                                                            
I prioritize movement, whether at the gym, at home or a walk on the beach.

I prioritize nutrition. No more living on caffeine and carbs.

I prioritize sleep and mindfulness. 

You simply cannot be switched on all the time. 

I am responsible for my energy and well-being.

They say the definition of insanity is doing the same thing repreatedly, expecting a different result.

Isn’t it funny how often entrepreneurs fall into this trap?

If there’s one thing working in the Capital Markets has taught me it’s this…

You should always expect the unexpected. 

That means knowing how and when to pivot is crucial. 

Which means knowing when to trust your gut and empirical data.

These are some of the signs it’s time to pivot:
• Stagnant or Declining Growth
• Changing Market Conditions
• Negative Market Feedback
• Resource Drains
• Investor Advice

Get out of the insanity loop.

Sometimes, a tweak in the right direction is all you need to set yourself on course again!

I am a student of my calendar.

What do I mean by that?

It means I study and plan where I spend my time to master time management, according to my goals.

Do you start your day by reacting to emails and messages, or do you strategically plan your time?

I've made mistakes I often see CEOs and entrepreneurs doing when they're not looking at their calendars strategically and holistically. 

Instead, they're working longer hours to fit everything in and/or reacting to what comes inbound towards them throughout the day. 

Then wondering why they never have time for their family or health and feel like they are burning the candle at both ends.

Here’s how to change that.

Review where you allocate your time and adapt. 

Block non-negotiable time for family and health. 

Make time for the gym and other priorities, rather than scheduling calls or responding to emails from the moment you wake up. 

If you want to meditate before starting your day, block that time in your calendar.

Plan strategically and focus your energy on what truly matters.

It’s part planning, part learning, part strategy. 

As Tony Robbins famously said, "Energy flows where attention goes."

Building a championship sports team

Approaching an IPO is a lot like assembling a championship sports team. 

As a coach, you’ll be selecting players based on their strengths and how well they fit together and similarly, you need to identify and connect with the right investors for your IPO.

·      Scouting Talent: Just like scouting for the best players, you need to research and understand potential investors. Get to know their strategies, what they look for in a company, and how they can complement your vision.

·      Building Chemistry: Investors, much like players, often operate within networks. Ensuring they work well together can lead to a more cohesive and supportive shareholder base, just like a well-synchronized team on the playing field.

·      Training Camps: Educate your investors about your company’s story and future potential. This is akin to training camps where players learn the playbook and get aligned with the team’s goals.

·      Game Day: Your company’s IPO is game day! Having investors (or 'supporters’) who understand and believe in your company can significantly impact your success.

·      Season Strategy: Post-IPO, you’ll continue to nurture these relationships. Just as a coach relies on the team throughout the season, you’ll need ongoing support from your investors for future initiatives.

This is such a critical part of the process, and if you want to know more about it, check out Chapter 8 in my book!

By focusing on these elements, you can create a strong foundation for your company’s growth and success in the public market.

Thank you to Elliot Milian for your input into this chapter!

Biotech IPOs in 2024: A Sign of Revival?

Rapport Therapeutics (RAPP) has successfully reopened the door for biotech IPOs with a 22.4% rise post-IPO, raising $136 million. 

This marks a significant moment after two months without any biotech listings.
Before Rapport's success, the sector had seen eight sizable biotech and clinical-stage device developers go public this year, most of which had poor returns. 

The year's first biotech IPO, CG Oncology (CGON), was the only one delivering a decent return, though even it fell short of the first-day close.

Rapport's strong performance may indicate a turning point for biotech IPOs in 2024. With more companies like CG Oncology showing potential, we could be witnessing the start of a biotech resurgence. 

Building on this momentum, biotech companies must leverage investor interest by sharing their stories and highlighting their innovative solutions. 

The market is watching closely, and the opportunities for growth and success are vast.

Choose your auditor carefully.

The recent SEC charges against BF Borgers CPA PC and its owner for "massive fraud" underscore the critical importance of carefully choosing auditors and professional advisors. The scandal affected over 1,500 SEC filings, leading to significant penalties and significant damage to issuers. 

Amid long-standing rumors, Borgers was found to have violated PCAOB standards, falsified audit documents, and misled clients about their compliance. 

Their actions also misrepresented the integrity of audits in over 500 public filings, seriously damaging the value, credibility and financial reporting transparency. 

It is hard to believe that BF Borgers was among the top 10 auditing firms with the most publicly traded clients in 2023.

For companies aiming to go public, selecting the right auditor is crucial. Auditors ensure that financial statements are accurate and meet the rigorous standards expected on major exchanges like NASDAQ or NYSE. 

Additionally, a knowledgeable IPO advisory firm is vital for navigating the complex IPO process, ensuring regulatory compliance, and maintaining effective communication with market regulators.

This case highlights the need for meticulous selection of financial partners, prioritizing deep regulatory understanding and unwavering professionalism. 

This approach not only ensures compliance but also positions a company for sustained success in the competitive public market landscape.

Here’s why Databricks is putting an IPO on hold— even though they’re ready. 
 
Wall Street has been expecting a Databricks IPO for a while now.  
 
And just when the markets seem right, they’re taking a different approach. 
 
Databricks is already operating as a public company, doing its audits and financials as a public company would.   
 
So why aren’t they going public yet? 
 
They’re choosing to act as a public firm by self-reporting business performance, as it waits for the right moment to commit to an IPO. 
 
This is what IPO readiness looks like.  
 
This is what preparing for an IPO well before you plan to IPO looks like. 
 
Databricks can choose their preferred market conditions. There is no rush or panic. 
 
This is why I will continue to talk about the immense value in not simply going public- but in IPO preparedness.  
 
Doing this teaches you the value of operating as a public entity before going public.  
 
That’s exactly why CEO Ali Ghodi says, “It feels like having your cake and eating it, too.”

In chapter 10 of my book, I dive deep into the pre-IPO roadshow and Testing the Waters period. 
 
You might have heard a lot of hype around Reddit’s pre-IPO roadshow which commenced this week. The Roadshow is a time-sensitive window before the IPO where many discussions on various topics will occur with the SEC, the exchange, and your bankers. 
 
During this time-sensitive window, the SEC will review your filing and provide comments and questions regarding your disclosures, your business, and the risk factors. The SEC will require complete disclosure of material information. Simultaneously, the exchange will review your application, provide comments, and ask questions regarding your application.
 
The primary reason for the IPO roadshow is to allow companies to generate enough interest from investors to raise the capital necessary to go from a private firm to a public one. In addition, it enables listing companies to understand their standing in the market. If done successfully, IPO roadshows can create an oversupply of capital to help drive a company’s long-term success and accelerate its growth.
 
I am so glad to have had input from Ross David Carmel, Esq. for this chapter. Ross provided the following tip for the Testing the Water period:
 
Testing the waters before you dive into a roadshow, allows you and the investment bank and you to give your presentation to institutional investors before your registration statement is publicly available. These meetings give companies a chance to gauge and generate investor interest in a public offering before engaging in a formal roadshow. It allows for a company to evaluate the market, and for the market, in turn, to evaluate the company exploring an IPO before expending additional costs and resources. Further, any feedback received during the testing of the waters process can be used to refine your presentation when going on the roadshow.
 
Thank you, Ross, for your invaluable contribution to this book!
 
#author #business #personal #roadshow #ipo

The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) made a historic move last week by voting to implement a rule mandating public companies to disclose specific climate-related risks. 

The regulation, although diluted from its initial draft, has triggered varied reactions; with some in favor and many against it. First proposed in March 2022, the SEC rule seeks to establish a standard for how companies communicate with investors regarding greenhouse gas emissions, climate-related risks, and their readiness for the transition to a low-carbon economy. 
SEC Chair Gary Gensler emphasized the neutrality of the disclosure, describing it as information that can be used for trading decisions without taking a stance.

While companies will need to append a note to financial statements outlining costs from severe weather events, the mandate to separate the impacts of these costs has been narrowed. Smaller firms, constituting the majority in the U.S., are exempt from reporting greenhouse gas emissions.
The SEC's decision to push for climate disclosures sets a significant precedent in financial regulation and aligns with broader efforts to address climate change threats through federal agencies.

Got Gilt???

The UK government has opened avenues for retail investors to participate in newly issued gilts, aiming to diversify its investor base amid record bond sales. A gilt is a UK Government liability denominated in sterling, issued by HM Treasury and listed on the London Stock Exchange. The term “gilt” or “gilt-edged security” is a reference to the primary characteristic of gilts as an investment: their security. 

Winterflood Securities, a designated government dealer for UK debt, is pioneering this shift, enabling individual investors to buy government bonds in the primary market through major retail investment platforms.

While private investors traditionally access government bonds on the secondary market, new bond issues, often launched at discounted prices, are predominantly available to institutional investors. Winterflood Securities sees this initiative as a means to provide an institutional level of access to retail investors, emphasizing that no transaction fees will be charged during the sales process.

This initiative highlights the UK's increased borrowing needs, with a gross financing requirement estimated at £277 billion for 2024-25. It also reflects a collaborative effort, with the Debt Management Office recognizing the value of a diverse investor base. The UK now joins other major bond markets, such as the US Treasury, in directly selling bonds to the public.

Participation in gilt auctions is initially available through Hargreaves Lansdown and interactive investor, two major UK investment platforms. Retail investors can order a seven-year gilt, issued on February 28, with a coupon of 4 percent. Unlike secondary market transactions, investors will not incur dealing fees, making it an attractive proposition.

I believe that this initiative is a significant step in recognizing retail investors, and consistent with ongoing efforts by regulatory bodies. 

While retail investors will initially participate in auctions of new gilts, there's potential for broader access in the future. This comes at a time when private investors have shown increased interest in gilt trading, evident in the rising trading volumes reported by platforms like Hargreaves Lansdown.

As retail investors secure a seat at the table, this development signifies a fundamental shift in the dynamics of UK bond markets.

The SEC has just voted 3-2 to implement rules aimed at providing greater clarity to Special Purpose Acquisition Company (SPAC) investors. 
 
In about five months, when these rules take effect, they will significantly realign SPAC regulations to mirror those of conventional IPOs, with a strong emphasis on transparency and protecting investors. This change is likely to further decrease the appeal of SPACs, a trend that was notably popular due to high market interest during 2020 and 2021.
 
The rules are designed to align SPAC investor protections with those of traditional IPOs by necessitating increased disclosures and making executives accountable for them. SEC chair, Gary Gensler emphasized that alternative methods of going public shouldn't exempt companies from established investor protections. However, the move faced opposition from those who argued that it could stifle a fundraising model deemed useful by certain companies. 
 
Notably, the once-booming SPAC fundraising, which witnessed over 860 SPACs raising $246 billion in 2020 and 2021, has markedly slowed down since 2022. Last year there were only 31 SPAC IPOs, raising $3.8 billion. 
 
The SEC's regulatory push, introduced in early 2022, has been cited as a significant factor contributing to this decline. The rules aim to address concerns about SPACs diluting cash by the time of a merger, impacting shareholder returns. The adopted rules mandate additional disclosure about potential dilution in standardized tables on key filings' cover pages. 
 
SPACs are also required to disclose conflicts of interest between sponsors or affiliates and ordinary shareholders, enhancing transparency. This regulatory intervention aligns with a broader trend of increased scrutiny of alternative fundraising models and underscores the SEC's commitment to investor protection and market integrity. 
 
The SPAC market, once dominant, now faces a challenging landscape reshaped by regulatory realities and changing investor sentiment.

This IPO is a significant step for Greece, aligning with the nation's history of utilizing state asset sales as a crucial component of international bailouts. These initiatives, totaling around 260 billion euros between 2010-2018, have played a pivotal role in attracting private investments, restructuring state entities, and mitigating the nation's debt, making it an imperative move for Greece's financial landscape.

A coalition of hedge fund groups has initiated legal action to challenge two US rules on short selling, claiming they are contradictory and risk exposing investors' positions. 
 
The groups argue that the SEC has taken an "arbitrary and capricious" approach, adopting rules without considering their combined impact. The legal challenge targets two SEC rules introduced in October. One rule mandates securities lenders to report each loan individually, with data made public the next business day. 
 
The other rule requires some institutional investors to report short-selling activity on an aggregated and delayed basis. The groups argue that the SEC has adopted fundamentally contradictory approaches, leading to regulatory inconsistency. The lawsuit is part of ongoing industry concerns that the SEC has introduced rules without considering their collective impact on the securities markets. 
 
The SEC defends its rulemaking as consistent with its authorities and governing laws and vows to defend the challenged rules in court vigorously. Interestingly, this legal action coincides with the UK moving in the opposite direction, removing transparency from short-selling practices.
 
The UK government unveiled a proposed statutory instrument last month that will replace the obligation for hedge funds to publicly reveal when they hold a short position in specific companies with an overall total for all companies.

An interesting situation unfolded early last week. A ransomware group, BlackCat is adapting its tactics by leveraging the upcoming SEC cyber incident reporting rules to intensify pressure on non-compliant organizations. In short, the hacker reported its victim to the SEC, for failing to disclose the data breach within the required 4-day window. 

The recent case involving MeridianLink, a provider of digital lending solutions, showcases the group's daring approach. Unlike many ransomware gangs, BlackCat didn't rely on file encryption; instead, they directly pursued data leak blackmail, revealing the breach on their data leak blog.

The backdrop to this data breach is the SEC's new cybersecurity reporting rules, scheduled to come into effect on December 15. These rules mandate that US-listed companies disclose cybersecurity incidents that materially impact the company's financial condition and operations within four business days of finding such incidents. 

While the SEC's rules represent a positive step towards transparency, incidents involving companies like MeridianLink underscore an uncomfortable truth—compliance alone is insufficient in the ever-evolving landscape of cybersecurity. The industry needs robust, always-on defenses and proactive strategies. 

The incident also highlights the criminal nature of ransomware groups and their primary motive—profits. As the industry grapples with these evolving threats, it emphasizes the urgency for a comprehensive and adaptive cybersecurity approach that goes beyond compliance.

The SEC lodged a complaint on Monday, alleging that SolarWinds, along with Chief Information Security Officer Tim Brown, misled investors by not disclosing "known risks" and inaccurately representing its cybersecurity measures. 

The alleged misconduct extends from at least the company's IPO in October 2018 to December 2020, encompassing when one of the most significant cyberattacks in recent history occurred. This incident brought unprecedented attention to SolarWinds, a hitherto little-known Austin-based supply chain company. The attack, orchestrated by hackers linked to Russian intelligence, exploited a SolarWinds software product to spy on businesses and government organizations worldwide, including the US Commerce and Treasury Departments.

The SEC's lawsuit is significant, marking the first attempt by the commission to hold a Chief Information Security Officer personally accountable for cybersecurity failures. This action aligns with Gary Gensler, the SEC Chair's, focus on cybersecurity risks, which includes proposing rules to expand companies' disclosures.

The SEC's complaint provides several instances where concerns about cybersecurity vulnerabilities were raised within SolarWinds. Brown's internal presentation from 2018 highlighted the "vulnerable state" of SolarWinds' security, although the company's IPO registration documents only included "generic and hypothetical cybersecurity risk disclosures." Further internal communications noted issues related to the capacity to address security concerns, suggesting a lack of resilience.

The SEC's allegations point to these shortcomings being exploited in what it describes as "one of the worst cybersecurity incidents in history," which transpired between January 2019 and December 2020.

This lawsuit adds a new dimension to the conversation around cybersecurity, emphasizing the responsibility of corporations to disclose known risks and implement adequate cybersecurity measures to protect their stakeholders.

After nearly three decades of consideration, The Philippine Stock Exchange, Inc. (PSE) welcomes legal short-selling. Beginning this week, 52 stocks and one exchange-traded fund, including all equities on the benchmark gauge, will be available for short-selling. This decision comes after regulators approved a proposal initially set forth by the Philippine Stock Exchange Inc. in 1996.

This decision to embrace short-selling is notable, especially as regional peers like China and South Korea are tightening control over it. Emerging markets are under the pressure of higher U.S. interest rates, making it a critical juncture for the Philippines to take this step.

Over the past decade, the Philippine stock market has seen a decline in daily stock transactions by almost 40%, and foreign equity investments are on track to shrink for a sixth consecutive year. 

The Philippine Depository and Trust Corp. holds the exclusive license to provide shares not owned for short-selling. Other brokers can lend out shares they own to clients or borrow stocks from the depository for a fee. While this opens up possibilities for lending agents, some brokers are in no hurry to obtain lending permits due to associated costs.

However, this change in the market comes at a time when the benchmark has declined nearly 9% in 2023, positioning it among the worst-performing markets in Asia. Foreign investors have withdrawn almost $6 billion from the country's equity markets since 2018.

Nevertheless, the ability to short-sell might not be the only factor to attract global funds. Ernest C., Portfolio Manager for Southeast Asia equities at BNP Paribas Asset Management, highlights a key challenge: "Liquidity has been one of the key constraints for foreign investors to build large positions in the Philippine stock market. Short selling might cause more unfavorable volatility, particularly in a market with lower liquidity." 

I am interested to see the impact this has on investor sentiment and market dynamics.

In the world of finance, volatility and the markets are inseparable companions. In my latest article for Entrepreneur Media, I delve into what makes an adaptive leader and why this is critical in today's volatile finance markets.

I've encountered both hardships and successes throughout my journey as an entrepreneur. These challenges have taught me the value of resilience and the importance of adaptability. As CEO of Exchange Listing, I've had the privilege of leading companies through the ever-changing IPO landscape. In a volatile environment like ours, adaptive leadership isn't just an option; it's a necessity.

Earlier this week, a stroll through Amsterdam to clear my head, led me past the Anne Frank House, a landmark near my apartment. 

This iconic home serves as a stark reminder of the persecution and resilience of Jews spanning from the time of the Holocaust to the establishment of Israel in 1948 and now to the current war.

As I watched tourists peacefully wait in line to get a look inside, I was struck by the parallels between the profound strength and perseverance of one remarkable little girl from many years ago, to the current suffering in war-torn locations around the world.

As a second-generation Holocaust survivor, I am familiar with the vigilance and resilience that are ingrained in the Jewish community. Picturing young Anne, who was around the same age as my Berlin-born mother, it struck me that like Anne and my mother, there are young children and adults forced into hiding from persecution at this very moment in time.

It is painfully evident that the trials facing humanity are not ancient history as we often imagine. It's impossible to ignore the distressing situation that's unfolding, not just in Israel and Gaza, but globally, leaving communities worldwide in a state of uncertainty. 

I was initially reluctant to share this post. My aim is not to delve into political or religious debates, nor to foster further division. Instead, I wish to advocate and stand for human decency: an ideal that knows no flag or faction and excuses no crimes against innocent civilians.

Recent IPOs by companies like Arm Holdings, Instacart, and Klaviyo have showcased cautious pricing and strategies in an IPO market that remains uncertain.

While these companies initially priced their offerings at the high end or above expectations and saw strong first-day trading, their shares later dropped, highlighting the market's continued volatility.

Renos Savvides, head of equity capital markets at Neuberger Berman, noted that until the trend of IPOs opening strong and then fading is addressed, the IPO market will continue to be uncertain. IPOs are crucial for capital formation and job creation in the U.S. When companies go public, they provide opportunities for employees and early investors to benefit. Younger companies listing their shares can offer significant gains for small public investors.

In 2021, the IPO market was booming, driven by investors seeking higher yields in a low-rate environment. However, the market dynamics shifted when the Federal Reserve began raising interest rates in late 2021. This shift led to a decline in the prices investors were willing to pay for high-growth companies, both publicly and privately. Traditional IPOs in the U.S. raised the lowest amount of money in at least two decades in 2022.

Instacart's recent IPO, which valued the company at $9.9 billion, was far below its $39 billion valuation in a 2021 funding round. This valuation cut is seen as a sign that the market has shifted away from the exuberance of 2021. Mark Caccavo, a general partner at Millennia Capital, noted that valuations are returning to more realistic levels, which could encourage more companies to go public.

While some recent listings, like Oddity Tech and Kenvue, are trading below their IPO values, others like Mobileye and Cava Group have seen gains. Looking ahead, companies like Birkenstock and Waystar are considering IPOs, with investors receptive to new issuances but focused on financial stability and growth catalysts.

The IPO market is showing signs of returning, but it remains volatile and uncertain. However, IPO advisers are fielding more inquiries from private companies considering going public, indicating continued interest in the IPO route. It will be interesting to see how the 2024 IPO landscape evolves. 

#markets #ipo #business #equity #capitalmarkets

The US has been a preferred destination for global companies seeking an IPO in recent years. 

Now, as the IPO market picks up steam, even foreign companies with established trading histories overseas are looking at US listings, attracted by the promise of higher valuations and increased liquidity.

Consider UK-based chip designer, Arm, which recently returned to the public markets by choosing to IPO in New York, despite pressure from UK officials to list in London. Arm had traded on the LSE for nearly two decades before going private in 2016 under Japan's SoftBank. Arm's $5 billion IPO generated significant buzz as it priced at the high end and saw a 25% surge, although it's currently trading 9% above its offer price.

In late July, US appliance manufacturer SharkNinja (SN) commenced trading on the NYSE after its Hong Kong-listed parent company, JS Global Lifestyle (HKEx: 1691), distributed shares of the core subsidiary to its shareholders. 

The US listing has so far unlocked substantial value for shareholders, with SharkNinja commanding a market cap of $6.2 billion, while JS Global stands at $0.6 billion. Before the spin-off, JS Global was worth about $3.6 billion.

Opting for a US listing offers several advantages, including access to the world's deepest and most liquid capital markets, as well as a vast base of potential institutional investors with experience valuing diverse businesses. Companies with well-known US consumer brands (Shark Ninja) may also find their customers eager to become investors.

Foreign companies have accounted for a significant portion of US IPO activity. Several foreign issuers have cross-listed in the US this year, including notable offerings from Mexico's Vesta Real Estate (VTMX) and Israel's Enlight Renewable Energy (ENLT).

While the public pipeline is full of foreign issuers, only six are currently registered to raise $100 million or more. Among the recent filers are Germany's Birkenstock (BIRK), reportedly planning to launch in the coming week if a government shutdown is avoided, and Vietnamese tech firm VNG (VNG), deferring its listing until 2024.

As the IPO market continues to gain momentum, the United States remains an attractive destination for foreign companies seeking to tap into its deep capital markets and broad investor base. The journey of these foreign-listed firms transitioning to US exchanges showcases the global appeal and opportunities that the US IPO landscape presents.

Abramovich, who served as the governor of Russia's Chukotka region from 2000 to 2008, has maintained a close relationship with the country's president, Vladimir Putin.

Abramovich is perhaps best recognized in Western spheres as the owner of the English football club Chelsea FC from 2003 until 2022 when the UK government took measures to freeze his assets and forced the sale of the club in response to the Kremlin's actions in Ukraine. The case exemplifies the interconnected nature of finance, politics, and international relations.

The SEC's action against Concord Management and Michael Matlin draws attention to the evolving regulatory landscape, highlighting the pitfalls of managing assets for clients with political clout. 

As financial markets become increasingly globalized and governments enact stricter measures, navigating these complex waters has never been more challenging. The case serves as a reminder of the importance of compliance with regulatory requirements and the potential legal ramifications that can arise when transparency is lacking in financial dealings.

This year, the competition between Nasdaq and the NYSE for new listings has been intense, with Nasdaq holding a slight lead in helping companies raise funds. 

For the past two decades, NYSE, housed in its iconic building in New York's downtown financial district, has traditionally been the frontrunner in securing new listings. However, Nasdaq, headquartered in the vibrant heart of Times Square, has been on a winning streak lately, especially as tech-related IPOs dominate the new listings arena.

There’s been a slight resurgence in the IPO market this year, though nowhere near the 2021 high. This month's offerings, including Instacart, feature more tech stocks compared to earlier this year when the market was largely dominated by non-tech offerings, like the $4.3 billion spin-off of Kenvue, the consumer brands arm of Johnson & Johnson, which chose NYSE.

The battle between these two premier exchanges is not just about fees but prestige. Winning a coveted listing generates annual fees and enhances the reputation of the chosen exchange. Executives often have a lot to consider when deciding between the two.

Nasdaq CEO Adena Friedman went to great lengths to secure Arm's recent listing. She even traveled to Japan to personally lobby Masayoshi Son, the founder of Arm's owner, SoftBank, for the listing. Arm's IPO on Nasdaq was a massive success, marking the largest IPO in nearly two years. The stock surged 25% on its first day of trading.

However, NYSE continues to attract companies that associate it with staying power and prestige. Executives who choose NYSE have the opportunity to ring its famous opening bell in front of live traders. It's a ceremony steeped in tradition and symbolizes a company's arrival on the global stage. On the other hand, Nasdaq offers a high-tech electronic billboard, located amid the dazzling lights of Times Square.

Nasdaq's appeal to smaller companies cannot be underestimated. The exchange's lower listing fees often attract capital-hungry biotechnology firms, which frequently tap the market for funds. This generates substantial fees for Nasdaq, especially since smaller biotech companies typically return to the market several times as they grow.

As the IPO market begins to regain momentum, both exchanges are gearing up to welcome a robust pipeline of companies. However, not all companies meet NYSE's listing standards, which may steer them towards Nasdaq.

The battle for listings is likely to remain a close contest this year, and each exchange will do its best to position itself as the exchange of choice for the most innovative and promising companies. The ongoing rivalry between these two giants ensures that companies and investors have a choice, whether they prefer NYSE's timeless prestige or Nasdaq's cutting-edge appeal.

Let me set the scene for you. Overlooking the amazing landscapes of Piedmont Italy, this sanctuary is steeped in centuries of history and spirituality. It’s something few people may get to see in their lifetimes. The Abbey sits at the top of a rocky mountain, seeming to come out of the mountain itself. Built at the end of the 10th century it is full of mystery and you really get that feeling when you visit (it’s probably also the 7 tombs inside and the countless symbolic images and carvings all over the church). 

The whole complex is dedicated to St Michael the Archangel and is one of 7 sanctuaries forming a perfectly straight line from England to Jerusalem. These seven shrines are quite similar to one another and are spaced at a certain distance apart. Here’s the crazy thing, on the day of the summer solstice, they are all along the line created by the setting sun. Christian symbolism connects this line to the way Archangel Michael descended to drive Lucifer out.

My visit prompted deep introspection. It was a reminder to slow down, breathe, and seek solace in the midst of life's hustle and bustle.

Wall Street is feeling the impact of rising inflation, and it's not just in its own operations. 

Large banks and brokerage firms are finding themselves writing bigger checks to settle regulatory investigations, even those that don't lead to financial losses for investors. U.S. market regulators are increasingly demanding tens of millions of dollars to settle technical violations, which just a few years ago, would have cost companies far less to resolve.

This past week, the SEC filed a lawsuit against Virtu Financial, one of Wall Street's major electronic traders. The SEC alleged that some Virtu employees might have improperly accessed the confidential trading information of clients, although no misuse of the data was claimed. Notably, the SEC sought a fine of over $25 million in this case, significantly more than what similar past cases had garnered.

Virtu's CEO, Douglas Cifu, decided to contest the SEC in court, citing that the SEC's settlement offers were not commercially reasonable. 

This development reflects a broader trend where regulatory bodies are increasing their enforcement efforts, seeking higher penalties, and in some cases, targeting individuals within organizations. 

While advocates of stricter financial regulation support this approach, they also emphasize the importance of pursuing legal action against individuals rather than relying solely on fines against institutions.

These escalating fines are generating pushback from defense lawyers and legal scholars, who argue that the SEC is exceeding historical norms in imposing penalties. Some legal groups are exploring ways to challenge the SEC's authority in civil enforcement cases.

The situation underscores the ongoing evolution of regulatory practices and the need for financial institutions to remain vigilant and compliant in an environment of heightened scrutiny.

I am honored to have been featured in Forbes Finance Council’s post, about how leaders can effectively manage risk and uncertainty. Navigating risk and uncertainty is the name of the game for modern business leaders. 

Adaptability is key in a landscape filled with economic shifts, tech advances, and rapid changes. So, here's some wisdom from fellow Forbes Finance Council members for your Friday:

Connect With Peers: Joining forces with entrepreneurial peers offers insights into challenges and solutions. These connections provide valuable support in dealing with business risks. - Allison Kelly 

Proactively Identify Risks: In our fast-paced world, proactive risk identification is vital. Diversifying, continuous learning, financial stability, and real-time risk monitoring turn challenges into opportunities. Regularly review strategies and communicate openly. - Michelle Austin CA (SA), Cert.Dir. 

Accept Risk and Uncertainty: Treat them as constants in business and life. Managing them is a vital skill for future leaders. - Vlad Spiridon, Novartis
Prioritize Resilience: Teach leaders to be resilient and action-oriented. Ensure cash availability through positive cash flow or capital raising. - Anisha Madan

Take Action: Don't be overly cautious. Promote a "fail and fail quick" mentality to manage risk. Overthinking stalls progress. Start with action and adjust as needed. - Austin Mac Nab

Pivot in Disruption: Understand the importance of pivoting when faced with disruption. Anticipate what could put you out of business and act accordingly. - Leo Kanell 

Communicate and Collaborate: Foster clear communication and collaboration at all levels. Seek input even on topics outside your direct authority. - Matt Barbieri

Don't Fear (the Right) Risks: While risk management is crucial, taking calculated risks can lead to significant rewards. Trust your instincts and don't shy away from calculated risks. - Will Murphy, EBSC

While we can’t eliminate risk entirely, mastering its management is how leaders steer their companies toward enduring success, regardless of external factors.

Surf Air Mobility which went public via direct listing in July has raised questions about the viability of direct listings, the once-buzzy alternative to traditional IPOs. 

The startup's shares, initially valued at $20 per share, saw a significant drop to $3.15 by the end of the first day, and they currently trade around $1.50 per share. Putting a major dent in the confidence of many considering this route.

In an environment where late-stage companies face financial challenges, founders are more inclined to seek the capital and backing that traditional IPO roadshows provide. Direct listings, once seen as bold and innovative, are now viewed as a daring move, mainly chosen by either companies with no other funding options or well-capitalized firms.

Spotify's direct listing in 2017 was a game-changer, signaling a shift in the approach to going public. However, Spotify was a well-known company with substantial resources. Then there was Slack's direct listing in 2019 as well as Palantir and Asana, who ventured into direct listings in late 2020 but they lacked the name recognition of Spotify and Slack.

While direct listings offer advantages such as avoiding underwriting fees and lockup periods, they might revert to being a last resort for companies in the current IPO landscape. Surf Air Mobility's decision to go public via direct listing came after a blank check merger fell through.

In the current cycle, fewer VC-backed companies are in a position to consider direct listings, because this method typically doesn't raise significant capital. The investor roadshow before an IPO remains valuable for a company, setting the share price and helping to establish the company's story.

Although a recent Supreme Court decision has made direct listings potentially more appealing to founders, as it reduces liability, the process sacrifices the support underwriters provide in marketing the listing to investors. This marketing helps prevent a disastrous market opening when investors are unfamiliar with the listing.

It’s clear that the landscape for direct listings is evolving, and it's no longer the go-to choice for companies seeking to go public. The decision between a direct listing and a traditional IPO is increasingly nuanced, with considerations of capital needs and market visibility playing crucial roles.

Nasdaq has just received the green light from the SEC for a big development in the world of financial trading. 

They're introducing the dynamic midpoint extended life order, or M-ELO, a sophisticated AI-driven order type set to revolutionize how trades are executed. 

Unlike traditional static orders, M-ELO employs real-time reinforcement learning AI to continuously analyze over 140 data points every 30 seconds, allowing it to adapt and optimize the timing of trade execution based on ever-changing market conditions. 

Nasdaq's research and testing indicate impressive results, with a 20.3% increase in fill rates and an 11.4% reduction in mark-outs. This innovation marks a significant step in the realm of algorithmic trading, where AI-driven solutions are increasingly transforming the financial landscape. 

Nasdaq continues to lead the charge in integrating AI into the finance sector, following previous successes such as predictive AI models for managing extensive options listings. 

As AI technologies continue to mature, their influence on finance, from traditional stocks to cryptocurrencies, is increasing and I expect we’ll see more of this kind of advancement in the near future.

Instacart's recent IPO filing revealed a paragraph that has generated heated debate this past week, with two companies, Instacart and Snowflake in the firing line.

Frank Slootman, the CEO of Snowflake, also sits on Instacart's board, and because of this connection, Instacart was required to disclose its business ties to Snowflake.

However, the disclosed figures initially raised concerns for Snowflake. Instacart stated that it made payments to Snowflake of $13 million in 2020, which increased to $28 million in 2021 and $51 million in 2022 for cloud-based data warehousing services.
 
However, the 2023 numbers seemed to show a sharp drop, with Instacart anticipating paying Snowflake approximately $15 million for the full year, a 71% decline in payments.

This apparent decline sparked controversy, with employees of Snowflake’s rival Databricks, suggesting on social media that it resulted from Instacart moving workloads to Databricks infrastructure. Snowflake countered that these figures were taken out of context.

The situation escalated this week, with posts on Reddit, LinkedIn, and other platforms, but many of these have since been deleted. Instacart also removed a blog post discussing its migration to Databricks' technology.
Snowflake and Databricks are fierce rivals in the cloud, data, and AI sectors, and their conflict has spilled over to social media in the past.

However, a deeper look reveals that the spending decline for 2023 is not as drastic as initially suggested. When accounting for operating expenses, Instacart's actual usage of Snowflake was $28 million in 2021, $28 million in 2022, and $11 million in the first half of 2023. This represents a 21% annualized drop instead of 71%.

Snowflake, in response to the controversy, published a blog post to clarify its perspective, emphasizing that it continues to work with Instacart to optimize efficiency and that its technology is extensively used by various teams within Instacart.

The controversy highlights the competitive landscape in the tech industry, where even indirect associations can spark debates, but often require a deeper understanding of the situation.
